items.text: I feel so restless that I can't sit still for more than a few minutes.
items.rationale: Psychomotor agitation and inability to remain still are core features of this factor.

items.text: I pace around the room without any clear purpose.
items.rationale: Purposeless pacing is a classic behavioral indicator of agitation.

items.text: My body feels wound up like a spring that can't uncoil.
items.rationale: Physical tension and a wound-up sensation directly reflect agitation.

items.text: People around me have noticed that I seem unable to relax.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of inability to relax maps clearly to agitation.

items.text: I keep wringing my hands or fidgeting with objects throughout the day.
items.rationale: Hand-wringing and fidgeting are hallmark psychomotor agitation behaviors.

items.text: I feel an inner restlessness that I just can't shake.
items.rationale: Subjective inner restlessness is a core experience of agitation in depression.

items.text: I have to keep moving or I feel like I'll crawl out of my skin.
items.rationale: Compulsive need to move and skin-crawling sensation are strong agitation indicators.

items.text: She can't stop tapping her foot and shifting in her chair during conversations.
items.rationale: Observable motor restlessness described from a third-person perspective.

items.text: I feel keyed up and on edge almost all the time now.
items.rationale: Feeling keyed up and on edge are direct descriptors of agitated states.

items.text: Even when I try to sit and watch television, I end up getting up repeatedly.
items.rationale: Inability to remain seated during a passive activity reflects psychomotor agitation.

items.text: My legs feel jittery and I can't keep them still.
items.rationale: Jittery legs and motor restlessness are somatic expressions of agitation.

items.text: I feel like there's nervous energy buzzing through my whole body.
items.rationale: Nervous energy throughout the body is a vivid description of agitation.

items.text: I feel tense and unsettled but I don't know why.
items.rationale: Tension and feeling unsettled map to agitation, though vague causelessness could overlap with anxiety or irritability.

items.text: I can't seem to settle down enough to get anything done.
items.rationale: Inability to settle maps to agitation, but the productivity component introduces some overlap with difficulty concentrating.

items.text: I feel so restless that I snap at people when they try to talk to me.
items.rationale: Restlessness is agitation, but snapping at others introduces clear irritability content.

items.text: I have almost no appetite anymore; food just doesn't appeal to me.
items.rationale: Loss of appetite and food aversion are core features of appetite changes in depression.

items.text: I've been eating much more than usual, especially comfort foods.
items.rationale: Increased eating and comfort food seeking reflect appetite changes in the opposite direction.

items.text: I have to force myself to eat because nothing tastes good.
items.rationale: Forcing oneself to eat and loss of taste pleasure are hallmarks of depressive appetite change.

items.text: My eating patterns have changed dramatically over the past few weeks.
items.rationale: Self-reported dramatic change in eating patterns directly maps to this factor.

items.text: I skip meals regularly now because I just don't feel hungry.
items.rationale: Meal skipping due to absent hunger signals is a clear appetite change indicator.

items.text: He has lost a noticeable amount of weight because he barely eats.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of weight loss due to reduced eating maps directly to appetite changes.

items.text: I crave food constantly and can't stop snacking even when I'm not hungry.
items.rationale: Constant cravings and eating beyond hunger reflect increased appetite in depression.

items.text: The thought of eating a full meal makes me feel nauseous.
items.rationale: Nausea at the thought of eating is a strong indicator of appetite suppression.

items.text: I've gained weight recently because I can't stop overeating.
items.rationale: Weight gain from overeating is a direct consequence of appetite increase in depression.

items.text: Food has become completely uninteresting to me.
items.rationale: Loss of interest in food is a core appetite change symptom.

items.text: I eat at irregular times and sometimes forget meals entirely.
items.rationale: Irregular eating and forgetting meals reflect disrupted appetite patterns.

items.text: My relationship with food has completely changed; I either eat too much or nothing at all.
items.rationale: Fluctuating between overeating and not eating captures the full spectrum of appetite changes.

items.text: I don't enjoy the foods I used to love.
items.rationale: Loss of food enjoyment maps to appetite changes but could also reflect broader anhedonia or loss of interest.

items.text: I eat to fill a void inside me, not because I'm actually hungry.
items.rationale: Emotional eating maps to appetite changes but the emotional void component could overlap with loss of interest or guilty feelings.

items.text: I've lost interest in cooking and preparing meals, so I just don't eat.
items.rationale: Not eating maps to appetite changes, but the loss of interest in the activity of cooking could reflect loss of interest more broadly.

items.text: I wake up several times during the night and can't fall back asleep.
items.rationale: Middle insomnia with difficulty returning to sleep is a classic depressive sleep disturbance.

items.text: I sleep far more than I used to, sometimes twelve or more hours a day.
items.rationale: Hypersomnia is a well-documented sleep pattern change in depression.

items.text: I lie awake for hours at night, unable to fall asleep.
items.rationale: Initial insomnia is a core sleep disturbance in depression.

items.text: My sleep schedule is completely disrupted; I'm up all night and sleep during the day.
items.rationale: Circadian rhythm disruption and reversed sleep-wake cycle map directly to sleep pattern changes.

items.text: I wake up hours before my alarm and can't get back to sleep.
items.rationale: Early morning awakening is a hallmark of depressive sleep disturbance.

items.text: No matter how much I sleep, I never feel rested.
items.rationale: Non-restorative sleep despite adequate duration is a key sleep quality complaint in depression.

items.text: She sleeps most of the day and still says she feels exhausted.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of hypersomnia with persistent exhaustion maps to sleep pattern changes.

items.text: I toss and turn all night and my sleep is very fragmented.
items.rationale: Fragmented, restless sleep is a direct indicator of sleep pattern disruption.

items.text: I dread going to bed because I know I'll just lie there staring at the ceiling.
items.rationale: Anticipatory dread of insomnia reflects chronic sleep pattern disturbance.

items.text: I need much more sleep than I used to just to get through the day.
items.rationale: Increased sleep need is a clear change in sleeping pattern.

items.text: I find myself napping during the day because I can't stay awake.
items.rationale: Excessive daytime sleepiness and napping reflect disrupted sleep patterns.

items.text: My sleep has changed so much that I barely recognize my old routine.
items.rationale: Self-reported dramatic change in sleep routine directly maps to this factor.

items.text: I feel drowsy and sluggish all day because I'm not sleeping well at night.
items.rationale: Daytime drowsiness from poor sleep maps to sleep changes, but sluggishness could overlap with loss of energy.

items.text: I can't sleep because my mind won't stop racing with thoughts.
items.rationale: Insomnia due to racing thoughts maps to sleep changes, but the cognitive component could overlap with agitation or difficulty concentrating.

items.text: I stay in bed all day not because I'm sleepy, but because I have no motivation to get up.
items.rationale: Staying in bed maps to sleep pattern changes, but the lack of motivation is more characteristic of loss of energy or loss of interest.

items.text: I cry almost every day now, often without any clear reason.
items.rationale: Frequent, unprovoked crying is a core indicator of the crying factor in depression.

items.text: I feel like crying all the time, even over the smallest things.
items.rationale: Persistent urge to cry with low threshold for tears maps directly to this factor.

items.text: I used to never cry, but now tears come easily and often.
items.rationale: A marked change from baseline in crying frequency is a clear depressive crying indicator.

items.text: I break down in tears at work and can't control it.
items.rationale: Uncontrollable crying in public or professional settings reflects significant crying symptoms.

items.text: He tears up during ordinary conversations for no apparent reason.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of unprovoked tearfulness maps clearly to crying.

items.text: I want to cry but I can't; the tears just won't come.
items.rationale: Inability to cry despite wanting to is recognized in the BDI as a crying-related symptom reflecting emotional numbness.

items.text: I find myself sobbing uncontrollably at random moments throughout the day.
items.rationale: Uncontrollable sobbing at random times is a severe manifestation of the crying factor.

items.text: Little things that never bothered me before now bring me to tears.
items.rationale: Lowered threshold for crying in response to minor stimuli is a hallmark of depressive crying.

items.text: I cry more now than I ever have in my life.
items.rationale: Self-reported increase in crying to unprecedented levels directly maps to this factor.

items.text: Once I start crying, I can't seem to stop for a long time.
items.rationale: Prolonged, difficult-to-stop crying episodes are a clear indicator of depressive crying.

items.text: I wake up in the morning already feeling like I'm about to cry.
items.rationale: Morning tearfulness upon waking is a strong indicator of pervasive crying symptoms.

items.text: My eyes are constantly red and puffy because I've been crying so much.
items.rationale: Physical evidence of frequent crying directly maps to this factor.

items.text: I feel a lump in my throat all day like I'm holding back tears.
items.rationale: The sensation of suppressed tears maps to crying, though the somatic lump-in-throat sensation could be interpreted more broadly.

items.text: I feel overwhelmed with sadness and it often comes out as tears.
items.rationale: Crying from sadness maps to this factor, but the overwhelming sadness component could reflect general depressive mood.

items.text: I get so frustrated with myself that I end up crying.
items.rationale: Crying is present, but the trigger is self-directed frustration which could map to guilty feelings or irritability.

items.text: I can't focus on anything for more than a few minutes before my mind drifts.
items.rationale: Inability to sustain focus with rapid mind-wandering is a core concentration difficulty.

items.text: I read the same paragraph over and over because nothing sinks in.
items.rationale: Rereading text without comprehension is a classic behavioral indicator of concentration problems.

items.text: My mind feels foggy and I can't think clearly.
items.rationale: Cognitive fog and unclear thinking are hallmarks of concentration difficulty in depression.

items.text: I have trouble following conversations because my mind keeps wandering.
items.rationale: Inability to track conversations due to mind-wandering directly reflects concentration problems.

items.text: I can't concentrate on my work the way I used to.
items.rationale: Decline in work-related concentration from baseline is a clear indicator of this factor.

items.text: He seems to zone out frequently and loses track of what's being discussed.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of zoning out and losing track maps directly to concentration difficulty.

items.text: Even simple tasks require enormous mental effort because I can't focus.
items.rationale: Disproportionate mental effort for simple tasks due to poor focus is a core concentration symptom.

items.text: I forget what I was doing in the middle of doing it.
items.rationale: Losing track of ongoing activities reflects significant concentration impairment.

items.text: I can't keep my thoughts organized; everything feels jumbled in my head.
items.rationale: Disorganized thinking and mental jumbling are direct indicators of concentration difficulty.

items.text: Watching a movie or TV show is impossible because I can't follow the plot.
items.rationale: Inability to follow narrative content reflects impaired sustained attention.

items.text: I make careless mistakes at work because I can't pay attention to details.
items.rationale: Careless errors from inattention to detail are behavioral consequences of concentration difficulty.

items.text: My thinking has slowed down so much that it takes me forever to process information.
items.rationale: Psychomotor slowing of cognitive processing is a recognized feature of concentration difficulty in depression.

items.text: I stare at my computer screen for long stretches without actually doing anything productive.
items.rationale: Staring without productivity suggests concentration problems, but could also reflect loss of energy or loss of interest.

items.text: I have trouble remembering things that people just told me.
items.rationale: Poor immediate recall maps to concentration, though memory complaints can be a broader cognitive symptom.

items.text: I can't focus enough to weigh my options when I need to make a choice.
items.rationale: Concentration difficulty is present, but the inability to weigh options for decision-making overlaps with indecisiveness.

items.text: I feel guilty about things that aren't even my fault.
items.rationale: Misplaced guilt over events outside one's control is a core feature of depressive guilt.

items.text: I constantly blame myself for everything that goes wrong.
items.rationale: Pervasive self-blame is a hallmark of guilty feelings in depression.

items.text: I feel like I've let everyone down.
items.rationale: Feeling of having disappointed others reflects interpersonal guilt central to this factor.

items.text: I believe I deserve the bad things that happen to me.
items.rationale: Belief in deserving punishment reflects severe depressive guilt.

items.text: I can't stop thinking about past mistakes and how I should have done things differently.
items.rationale: Rumination over past mistakes with self-recrimination is a core guilt symptom.

items.text: I feel responsible for other people's unhappiness.
items.rationale: Assuming responsibility for others' emotional states reflects excessive depressive guilt.

items.text: She constantly apologizes for things that aren't her fault.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of excessive apologizing maps to guilty feelings.

items.text: I feel like a burden to the people around me.
items.rationale: Perceived burdensomeness is closely tied to guilt and self-blame in depression.

items.text: I am haunted by guilt over things I did years ago.
items.rationale: Persistent guilt over distant past events is a clear indicator of depressive guilt.

items.text: I feel like I'm being punished for something, even though I can't say what.
items.rationale: A vague sense of deserved punishment is a recognized feature of depressive guilt.

items.text: I criticize myself harshly for every little mistake.
items.rationale: Harsh self-criticism over minor errors reflects the self-punitive aspect of guilty feelings.

items.text: I feel guilty even when I try to do something enjoyable for myself.
items.rationale: Guilt triggered by self-care or pleasure is a characteristic depressive guilt pattern.

items.text: I keep replaying situations in my head, wishing I had acted differently.
items.rationale: Replaying situations with regret maps to guilt, but the ruminative quality could overlap with difficulty concentrating.

items.text: I feel like I'm not good enough no matter what I do.
items.rationale: Feelings of inadequacy map to guilt and self-blame, though they could also reflect broader low self-worth.

items.text: I feel so guilty about not being productive that I can't enjoy my time off.
items.rationale: Guilt is the primary emotion, but the productivity concern and inability to enjoy leisure could map to loss of interest.

items.text: I can't make even the simplest decisions anymore.
items.rationale: Inability to make simple decisions is the core feature of depressive indecisiveness.

items.text: Choosing what to wear in the morning feels like an overwhelming task.
items.rationale: Being overwhelmed by trivial daily choices is a hallmark of depressive indecisiveness.

items.text: I go back and forth on decisions and can never commit to a choice.
items.rationale: Vacillation and inability to commit to choices directly maps to indecisiveness.

items.text: I avoid making decisions because I'm afraid I'll make the wrong one.
items.rationale: Decision avoidance driven by fear of error is a core indecisiveness pattern.

items.text: I put off decisions for as long as possible, hoping someone else will decide for me.
items.rationale: Procrastinating decisions and deferring to others reflects significant indecisiveness.

items.text: He can't decide what to order at a restaurant and agonizes over the menu.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of agonizing over a simple menu choice maps clearly to indecisiveness.

items.text: Every decision feels like it carries enormous weight, even when it doesn't matter.
items.rationale: Disproportionate perceived importance of minor decisions is a key feature of depressive indecisiveness.

items.text: I second-guess every choice I make, no matter how small.
items.rationale: Persistent second-guessing of all choices is a direct indicator of indecisiveness.

items.text: I feel paralyzed when I'm faced with a decision.
items.rationale: Decision paralysis is a vivid and accurate description of severe indecisiveness.

items.text: I used to be decisive, but now I can't seem to make up my mind about anything.
items.rationale: A change from baseline decisiveness to current indecision maps directly to this factor.

items.text: I ask other people to make decisions for me because I don't trust my own judgment.
items.rationale: Relying on others due to self-doubt in judgment is a behavioral manifestation of indecisiveness.

items.text: Making plans for the future feels impossible because I can't decide on anything.
items.rationale: Inability to plan due to decision-making difficulty directly reflects indecisiveness.

items.text: I spend so long deliberating that opportunities pass me by.
items.rationale: Excessive deliberation maps to indecisiveness, though missed opportunities could also reflect loss of interest or energy.

items.text: I can't decide what's important anymore; everything feels equally meaningless.
items.rationale: Inability to prioritize maps to indecisiveness, but the meaninglessness component could overlap with loss of interest.

items.text: I can't decide whether to keep going with my hobbies or just give them up entirely.
items.rationale: Indecision is present, but the content about potentially abandoning hobbies overlaps with loss of interest.

items.text: I get annoyed by things that never used to bother me.
items.rationale: Lowered threshold for annoyance compared to baseline is a core feature of depressive irritability.

items.text: I snap at my family members over trivial things.
items.rationale: Snapping at loved ones over minor issues is a hallmark behavioral indicator of irritability.

items.text: Everything and everyone irritates me lately.
items.rationale: Pervasive irritation with people and situations directly maps to irritability.

items.text: I feel angry and short-tempered most of the time.
items.rationale: Chronic anger and short temper are core features of depressive irritability.

items.text: Small inconveniences make me disproportionately upset.
items.rationale: Disproportionate emotional reactions to minor inconveniences reflect heightened irritability.

items.text: She has become much more short-tempered and easily frustrated than she used to be.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of increased short temper and frustration maps directly to irritability.

items.text: I lose my patience with people much faster than I used to.
items.rationale: Decreased patience compared to baseline is a clear indicator of irritability.

items.text: I feel like I'm constantly on the verge of blowing up at someone.
items.rationale: Feeling on the verge of an outburst reflects significant irritability.

items.text: Noise that I used to tolerate now makes me want to scream.
items.rationale: Reduced tolerance for sensory stimuli like noise is a common manifestation of irritability.

items.text: I find myself getting into arguments more often because I can't control my temper.
items.rationale: Increased interpersonal conflict from poor temper control is a behavioral consequence of irritability.

items.text: I feel irritated the moment I wake up in the morning.
items.rationale: Morning irritation upon waking reflects pervasive irritability.

items.text: Other people's habits and mannerisms drive me crazy in a way they never did before.
items.rationale: New intolerance of others' behaviors compared to baseline is a clear irritability indicator.

items.text: I feel frustrated with myself and everyone around me.
items.rationale: Frustration with self and others maps to irritability, though self-directed frustration could overlap with guilty feelings.

items.text: I get so irritated that I can't sit still or focus on what I'm doing.
items.rationale: Irritability is the primary emotion, but the inability to sit still and focus introduces overlap with agitation and difficulty concentrating.

items.text: I feel restless and agitated, and the slightest thing sets me off.
items.rationale: Being set off by small things is irritability, but the restlessness and agitation directly overlap with the agitation factor.

items.text: I feel completely drained of energy, even after doing nothing all day.
items.rationale: Feeling drained despite inactivity is a core feature of depressive fatigue and energy loss.

items.text: Everything takes so much more effort than it used to.
items.rationale: Increased effort for routine activities is a hallmark of energy loss in depression.

items.text: I feel physically exhausted from the moment I wake up.
items.rationale: Morning exhaustion upon waking directly reflects loss of energy.

items.text: I don't have the energy to do basic things like shower or get dressed.
items.rationale: Inability to perform basic self-care due to energy depletion is a severe indicator of this factor.

items.text: My body feels heavy, like I'm moving through mud.
items.rationale: Leaden paralysis and heaviness are classic somatic descriptions of energy loss in depression.

items.text: He barely has the energy to get off the couch most days.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of extreme low energy and inactivity maps directly to loss of energy.

items.text: I get tired after the smallest physical activity.
items.rationale: Fatigue from minimal exertion is a clear indicator of energy loss.

items.text: I feel like my batteries are permanently dead.
items.rationale: Metaphor of permanently dead batteries vividly captures chronic energy depletion.

items.text: I used to be active and energetic, but now I can barely function.
items.rationale: Decline from active baseline to barely functioning reflects significant energy loss.

items.text: Just the thought of doing chores makes me feel exhausted.
items.rationale: Anticipatory fatigue from merely thinking about tasks is a strong energy loss indicator.

items.text: I have to rest after climbing a single flight of stairs.
items.rationale: Needing rest after minimal physical exertion directly reflects energy depletion.

items.text: I feel like I'm running on empty all the time.
items.rationale: Running on empty is a common and accurate metaphor for chronic energy loss.

items.text: I'm too tired to keep up with my responsibilities.
items.rationale: Fatigue interfering with responsibilities maps to energy loss, though the inability to keep up could also reflect difficulty concentrating.

items.text: I feel physically and mentally wiped out by the end of the morning.
items.rationale: Being wiped out by morning maps to energy loss, but the mental component could overlap with difficulty concentrating.

items.text: I'm too exhausted to do the things I used to enjoy.
items.rationale: Exhaustion is the stated reason, mapping to energy loss, but not doing enjoyable activities also maps to loss of interest.

items.text: I've lost interest in hobbies and activities that I used to love.
items.rationale: Loss of interest in previously enjoyed activities is the defining feature of this factor.

items.text: Nothing excites me or makes me feel enthusiastic anymore.
items.rationale: Absence of excitement and enthusiasm reflects pervasive anhedonia and loss of interest.

items.text: I don't care about things that used to matter a lot to me.
items.rationale: Indifference toward previously valued things is a core indicator of loss of interest.

items.text: I go through the motions of my daily life without feeling engaged in any of it.
items.rationale: Going through the motions without engagement reflects the emotional detachment of loss of interest.

items.text: I used to look forward to weekends, but now they feel just as empty as weekdays.
items.rationale: Loss of anticipatory pleasure for leisure time is a clear loss of interest indicator.

items.text: She stopped attending her book club and no longer returns friends' calls.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of social and hobby withdrawal maps directly to loss of interest.

items.text: I don't get pleasure from anything anymore, not even things that should make me happy.
items.rationale: Anhedonia and inability to derive pleasure are core features of loss of interest.

items.text: I've stopped making plans with friends because I just don't feel like socializing.
items.rationale: Social withdrawal due to lack of desire to socialize reflects loss of interest in relationships.

items.text: Activities that once brought me joy now feel pointless.
items.rationale: Previously joyful activities feeling pointless is a direct expression of loss of interest.

items.text: I can't remember the last time I genuinely enjoyed doing something.
items.rationale: Inability to recall recent enjoyment reflects sustained loss of interest and pleasure.

items.text: I've withdrawn from most of my social activities and prefer to be alone.
items.rationale: Social withdrawal and preference for isolation are behavioral manifestations of loss of interest.

items.text: The things I used to be passionate about feel completely meaningless now.
items.rationale: Loss of passion and sense of meaninglessness about former interests directly maps to this factor.

items.text: I watch other people enjoying themselves and wonder why I can't feel that way.
items.rationale: Observing others' enjoyment with personal inability to feel it maps to loss of interest, though the wondering component could reflect broader depressive cognition.

items.text: I feel disconnected from the world around me, like I'm just an observer.
items.rationale: Feeling disconnected and like an observer maps to loss of interest and engagement, though it could also reflect depersonalization.

items.text: I don't bother doing things anymore because I don't have the energy or the desire.
items.rationale: Lack of desire maps to loss of interest, but the explicit mention of lacking energy introduces overlap with loss of energy.

items.text: I have almost no interest in sexual activity anymore.
items.rationale: Directly states a loss of sexual interest, the core of this factor.

items.text: Sex just doesn't appeal to me the way it used to.
items.rationale: Describes a decline in sexual appeal, clearly mapping to this factor.

items.text: I could go months without any sexual contact and it wouldn't bother me.
items.rationale: Indicates indifference to sexual contact, a hallmark of this factor.

items.text: My desire for intimacy has completely disappeared.
items.rationale: Reports complete loss of desire for physical intimacy.

items.text: I have lost all interest in being physically close with my partner.
items.rationale: Clearly describes loss of interest in physical closeness and sexuality.

items.text: When my partner initiates intimacy, I feel nothing at all.
items.rationale: Describes emotional and physical flatness in response to sexual initiation.

items.text: I used to have a healthy sex drive, but now it's essentially gone.
items.rationale: Explicitly contrasts past sexual drive with current absence.

items.text: Sexual thoughts rarely if ever cross my mind these days.
items.rationale: Reports absence of sexual thoughts, a cognitive marker of this factor.

items.text: I avoid situations that might lead to sexual activity.
items.rationale: Behavioral avoidance of sexual situations reflects diminished interest.

items.text: Physical intimacy feels like a chore rather than something enjoyable.
items.rationale: Describes sexual activity as burdensome, indicating loss of interest.

items.text: I can't remember the last time I felt any sexual desire.
items.rationale: Reports prolonged absence of sexual desire.

items.text: My libido has dropped to practically zero.
items.rationale: Direct statement about near-total loss of libido.

items.text: I feel disconnected from my body during any kind of intimate moment.
items.rationale: Disconnection during intimacy could reflect loss of sexual interest but also dissociation or emotional numbness more broadly.

items.text: I just don't feel any spark or attraction toward anyone lately.
items.rationale: Could reflect loss of sexual interest specifically or a broader anhedonia and emotional flatness.

items.text: I have no desire for intimacy and I can't enjoy anything physical or emotional with my partner.
items.rationale: The inability to enjoy anything emotional with a partner overlaps with Loss of Pleasure (anhedonia) more broadly.

items.text: Nothing brings me joy anymore, not even things I used to love.
items.rationale: Classic anhedonia statement describing loss of enjoyment in previously pleasurable activities.

items.text: I go through the motions of my hobbies but feel nothing.
items.rationale: Describes behavioral engagement without emotional reward, core to anhedonia.

items.text: Activities that once excited me now feel completely flat and meaningless.
items.rationale: Directly contrasts past excitement with current emotional flatness.

items.text: I don't look forward to anything anymore.
items.rationale: Absence of anticipatory pleasure is a key feature of anhedonia.

items.text: Even spending time with my closest friends feels empty.
items.rationale: Loss of pleasure in social connection, a strong indicator of this factor.

items.text: Food has lost its taste; I eat because I have to, not because I want to.
items.rationale: Loss of gustatory pleasure is a common somatic manifestation of anhedonia.

items.text: I can't remember the last time I genuinely laughed or smiled.
items.rationale: Absence of positive emotional expression reflects deep anhedonia.

items.text: Weekends and holidays feel no different from any other day.
items.rationale: Inability to experience pleasure during typically enjoyable times.

items.text: I've stopped doing things I used to enjoy because they don't feel rewarding.
items.rationale: Behavioral withdrawal driven by loss of reward, a hallmark of anhedonia.

items.text: Music, movies, and books that I once loved now leave me feeling nothing.
items.rationale: Loss of aesthetic and entertainment pleasure clearly maps to this factor.

items.text: I feel like the color has drained out of my life.
items.rationale: Metaphorical description of pervasive loss of pleasure and vitality.

items.text: There is no activity that can lift my mood, no matter what I try.
items.rationale: Reports inability to derive mood improvement from any activity.

items.text: I feel emotionally numb most of the time and can't connect with positive feelings.
items.rationale: Emotional numbness is related to anhedonia but could also reflect broader depressive affect or sadness.

items.text: I've withdrawn from social events because nothing feels worth the effort.
items.rationale: Social withdrawal could reflect anhedonia but also fatigue or pessimism about outcomes.

items.text: Everything feels pointless and I can't enjoy anything or see any reason to keep trying.
items.rationale: The sense of pointlessness and hopelessness overlaps significantly with Pessimism.

items.text: When I look back on my life, all I can see is a string of failures.
items.rationale: Directly reflects rumination on past failures, the core of this factor.

items.text: I have failed more than most people I know.
items.rationale: Social comparison emphasizing personal failure history.

items.text: I can't think of a single thing I've truly succeeded at.
items.rationale: Absolute negation of past success, a cognitive distortion typical of this factor.

items.text: My life has been full of disappointments and missed opportunities.
items.rationale: Retrospective focus on disappointments and lost chances.

items.text: I feel like I've wasted my potential and have nothing to show for my efforts.
items.rationale: Perception of wasted potential is a key cognitive theme in past failure rumination.

items.text: Every important decision I've made has turned out to be the wrong one.
items.rationale: Overgeneralized belief about poor decision-making reflects past failure cognitions.

items.text: I keep thinking about all the times I let people down.
items.rationale: Rumination on interpersonal failures and letting others down.

items.text: Looking at where I am in life, I feel like a complete failure.
items.rationale: Global self-assessment as a failure based on life outcomes.

items.text: I've never been able to finish anything important that I started.
items.rationale: Perception of chronic inability to complete goals reflects past failure beliefs.

items.text: My career has been one setback after another with no real achievements.
items.rationale: Domain-specific (career) focus on accumulated setbacks and lack of achievement.

items.text: I think about my past mistakes constantly and can't let them go.
items.rationale: Ruminative focus on past mistakes is central to this factor.

items.text: I have accomplished far less than I should have by this point in my life.
items.rationale: Perceived underachievement relative to expectations reflects past failure cognitions.

items.text: I feel ashamed when I think about how little I've achieved compared to others.
items.rationale: Shame about underachievement maps to past failure but the shame component could overlap with Self-Dislike.

items.text: I dwell on things that went wrong years ago and blame myself for them.
items.rationale: Self-blame for past events could overlap with Self-Criticalness, though the focus on past events anchors it here.

items.text: I've failed at so many things that I'm convinced I'll never succeed at anything in the future.
items.rationale: The future-oriented hopelessness component overlaps with Pessimism, though it is rooted in past failure.

items.text: I feel like things will only get worse from here.
items.rationale: Direct expression of negative future expectation, the core of pessimism.

items.text: I don't expect anything good to happen to me anymore.
items.rationale: Absence of positive future expectations is a hallmark of pessimistic thinking.

items.text: No matter what I do, my situation is never going to improve.
items.rationale: Hopelessness about change despite effort is central to pessimism.

items.text: The future looks dark and hopeless to me.
items.rationale: Classic hopelessness statement about the future.

items.text: I believe that my problems are permanent and will never be resolved.
items.rationale: Stable, global attribution about problems reflects pessimistic cognitive style.

items.text: I see no reason to be hopeful about anything.
items.rationale: Generalized absence of hope directly maps to pessimism.

items.text: When I think about the future, all I feel is dread.
items.rationale: Negative emotional response to future contemplation reflects pessimistic outlook.

items.text: I'm convinced that things are going to turn out badly no matter what.
items.rationale: Certainty about negative outcomes is a core pessimistic cognition.

items.text: There's nothing to look forward to in my life.
items.rationale: Absence of anticipation for positive future events.

items.text: I feel trapped in a life that will never get better.
items.rationale: Feeling trapped with no prospect of improvement is a strong pessimism indicator.

items.text: I've given up hoping that my life will change for the better.
items.rationale: Abandonment of hope for positive change is quintessential pessimism.

items.text: Every plan I make feels pointless because nothing will work out anyway.
items.rationale: Futility of planning due to expected negative outcomes reflects pessimism.

items.text: I wake up each morning with a sense of dread about what the day will bring.
items.rationale: Morning dread about the day could reflect pessimism but also overlaps with sadness or anxiety.

items.text: I can't imagine ever feeling happy again.
items.rationale: Inability to imagine future happiness is pessimistic but could also reflect current anhedonia (Loss of Pleasure).

items.text: I feel so hopeless that I sometimes wonder if life is even worth living.
items.rationale: The questioning of life's worth crosses into Suicidal Thoughts or Wishes territory.

items.text: I feel like I'm being punished for something I've done wrong.
items.rationale: Direct expression of feeling punished, the core of this factor.

items.text: I believe I deserve the bad things that happen to me.
items.rationale: Belief in deserving negative outcomes reflects punishment cognitions.

items.text: I expect to be punished for my mistakes.
items.rationale: Anticipation of punishment is a direct marker of this factor.

items.text: Bad things keep happening to me and I think it's because I deserve them.
items.rationale: Causal attribution of negative events to personal deservingness.

items.text: I feel like the universe is punishing me for who I am.
items.rationale: Externalized punishment belief tied to identity.

items.text: When something goes wrong, I immediately think it's my punishment.
items.rationale: Automatic cognitive interpretation of negative events as punishment.

items.text: I feel like I'm paying for sins I can't even identify.
items.rationale: Vague sense of being punished without clear cause is characteristic of this factor.

items.text: I think God or fate is punishing me.
items.rationale: Attribution of punishment to a higher power or fate.

items.text: My suffering feels like a just consequence for the kind of person I've been.
items.rationale: Links suffering to personal character as deserved punishment.

items.text: I constantly feel like I need to atone for something.
items.rationale: Persistent need for atonement reflects underlying punishment beliefs.

items.text: I believe my unhappiness is a form of punishment that I've earned.
items.rationale: Directly frames unhappiness as earned punishment.

items.text: Every setback feels like a deliberate punishment aimed at me.
items.rationale: Personalization of setbacks as targeted punishment.

items.text: I carry a heavy sense of guilt, as if I'm always doing something wrong that warrants consequences.
items.rationale: Guilt and expectation of consequences map to punishment feelings but guilt alone could reflect Self-Criticalness.

items.text: I feel like I don't deserve good things because of who I am.
items.rationale: Feeling undeserving could reflect punishment beliefs or Self-Dislike.

items.text: I hate myself for the things I've done and I feel like I deserve to suffer for them.
items.rationale: Self-hatred component overlaps significantly with Self-Dislike, though the deserving-to-suffer element anchors it in punishment.

items.text: I feel sad nearly all the time and I can't shake it.
items.rationale: Persistent sadness is the defining feature of this factor.

items.text: A deep sadness follows me everywhere I go.
items.rationale: Pervasive, inescapable sadness clearly maps to this factor.

items.text: I feel like crying most of the time, even when there's no obvious reason.
items.rationale: Tearfulness without clear trigger is a behavioral manifestation of sadness.

items.text: I am so unhappy that I can't stand it.
items.rationale: Intense, unbearable unhappiness directly reflects the sadness factor.

items.text: There is a constant heaviness in my chest that won't go away.
items.rationale: Somatic description of emotional heaviness associated with persistent sadness.

items.text: I feel down and blue every single day.
items.rationale: Daily experience of feeling down is a core sadness indicator.

items.text: My mood is so low that it feels like I'm drowning in sorrow.
items.rationale: Metaphorical description of overwhelming sadness.

items.text: I feel an emptiness inside that nothing can fill.
items.rationale: Inner emptiness is a common phenomenological description of depressive sadness.

items.text: I wake up feeling miserable and the feeling lasts all day.
items.rationale: Morning-onset persistent misery is characteristic of depressive sadness.

items.text: I feel so sad that it physically hurts.
items.rationale: Somatization of sadness into physical pain.

items.text: Even on days when good things happen, I still feel deeply unhappy.
items.rationale: Sadness that persists despite positive events indicates pervasive depressive mood.

items.text: I feel a profound sense of grief, though I can't always say what I'm grieving.
items.rationale: Unexplained grief-like sadness is a hallmark of depressive sadness.

items.text: I feel emotionally flat and hollow, like all the life has been drained out of me.
items.rationale: Emotional flatness could reflect sadness but also overlaps with Loss of Pleasure (anhedonia).

items.text: I feel unhappy and discouraged about everything in my life.
items.rationale: Discouragement about everything could reflect sadness or pessimism about the future.

items.text: I am so sad and hopeless that I feel like giving up on everything.
items.rationale: The hopelessness and giving-up component overlaps with Pessimism and potentially Suicidal Thoughts.

items.text: I am constantly finding fault with myself.
items.rationale: Persistent self-criticism is the defining feature of this factor.

items.text: I blame myself for everything that goes wrong.
items.rationale: Excessive self-blame is a core component of self-criticalness.

items.text: I criticize myself harshly for every small mistake.
items.rationale: Disproportionate self-criticism for minor errors directly maps to this factor.

items.text: No matter what I accomplish, I always focus on what I did wrong.
items.rationale: Selective attention to flaws despite accomplishments reflects self-critical cognitive bias.

items.text: I hold myself to impossibly high standards and then berate myself for falling short.
items.rationale: Perfectionism combined with self-punishment for not meeting standards.

items.text: My inner voice is constantly telling me I'm not good enough.
items.rationale: Negative internal dialogue about inadequacy is a hallmark of self-criticalness.

items.text: I replay my mistakes over and over, criticizing myself each time.
items.rationale: Ruminative self-criticism about past errors.

items.text: I am my own worst critic and I never give myself a break.
items.rationale: Self-identification as excessively self-critical with no self-compassion.

items.text: I judge myself more harshly than anyone else ever would.
items.rationale: Recognition that self-judgment exceeds external judgment reflects insight into self-criticalness.

items.text: When I make a mistake, I can't forgive myself for days.
items.rationale: Inability to self-forgive after errors is a behavioral consequence of self-criticalness.

items.text: I constantly second-guess myself and then criticize the decisions I've made.
items.rationale: Self-doubt followed by self-criticism reflects the cognitive pattern of this factor.

items.text: I feel like nothing I do is ever good enough.
items.rationale: Pervasive sense of inadequacy in performance reflects chronic self-criticism.

items.text: I spend a lot of time thinking about my flaws and shortcomings.
items.rationale: Rumination on flaws maps to self-criticalness but could also reflect Self-Dislike if focused on the self as a whole.

items.text: I feel guilty about things that most people wouldn't think twice about.
items.rationale: Excessive guilt could reflect self-criticalness but also overlaps with Punishment Feelings.

items.text: I criticize myself so much that I've started to truly dislike who I am as a person.
items.rationale: The transition from self-criticism to global self-dislike crosses into Self-Dislike territory.

items.text: I don't like who I am as a person.
items.rationale: Direct statement of disliking oneself, the core of this factor.

items.text: I am disgusted with myself.
items.rationale: Self-disgust is a strong indicator of self-dislike.

items.text: I feel contempt for myself when I look in the mirror.
items.rationale: Self-contempt triggered by self-perception reflects deep self-dislike.

items.text: I am deeply disappointed in the person I've become.
items.rationale: Global disappointment in oneself as a person maps to self-dislike.

items.text: I can't stand being around myself; if I could escape my own skin, I would.
items.rationale: Desire to escape oneself reflects extreme self-dislike.

items.text: I feel like there is something fundamentally wrong with me as a person.
items.rationale: Belief in a fundamental personal defect is central to self-dislike.

items.text: I look at other people and wish I could be anyone but myself.
items.rationale: Desire to be someone else reflects rejection of one's own identity.

items.text: I have lost all respect for myself.
items.rationale: Loss of self-respect is a direct manifestation of self-dislike.

items.text: I feel worthless as a human being.
items.rationale: Feelings of worthlessness reflect global negative self-evaluation.

items.text: I hate the person I see when I look at myself honestly.
items.rationale: Self-hatred upon honest self-reflection is a strong self-dislike indicator.

items.text: There is nothing about myself that I find likable or valuable.
items.rationale: Complete absence of positive self-regard reflects pervasive self-dislike.

items.text: I feel repulsed by my own character and personality.
items.rationale: Self-repulsion directed at character traits is a strong marker of self-dislike.

items.text: I am ashamed of who I am at my core.
items.rationale: Core shame maps to self-dislike but shame could also relate to Punishment Feelings or Past Failure.

items.text: I feel inferior to everyone around me in every way.
items.rationale: Pervasive inferiority reflects self-dislike but could also stem from Past Failure comparisons.

items.text: I despise myself so much that I sometimes think the world would be better off without me.
items.rationale: The belief that the world would be better without oneself crosses into Suicidal Thoughts or Wishes.

items.text: I have thought about killing myself.
items.rationale: Direct report of suicidal ideation, the core of this factor.

items.text: I wish I were dead.
items.rationale: Death wish is a direct expression of suicidal thinking.

items.text: I have considered ending my own life more than once.
items.rationale: Recurrent suicidal ideation clearly maps to this factor.

items.text: I sometimes think about how I would end my life if I decided to.
items.rationale: Planning or method consideration is a serious indicator of suicidal thinking.

items.text: I feel like my family and friends would be better off if I were gone.
items.rationale: Perceived burdensomeness is a well-established risk factor and cognition in suicidal ideation.

items.text: I would kill myself if I had the chance.
items.rationale: Expression of intent to act on suicidal thoughts given opportunity.

items.text: The thought of not existing brings me a sense of relief.
items.rationale: Finding relief in the idea of non-existence reflects passive suicidal ideation.

items.text: I have written or thought about writing a note to explain why I want to die.
items.rationale: Consideration of a suicide note indicates advanced suicidal planning.

items.text: I think about death as an escape from my pain.
items.rationale: Viewing death as escape from suffering is a common suicidal cognition.

items.text: I don't see any reason to go on living.
items.rationale: Absence of reasons to live is a critical suicidal risk cognition.

items.text: I have had recurring thoughts that life is not worth living.
items.rationale: Recurrent thoughts that life lacks worth directly map to suicidal ideation.

items.text: I sometimes wish I could just fall asleep and never wake up.
items.rationale: Passive death wish expressed as desire to not wake up.

items.text: I feel so trapped that ending my life seems like the only way out.
items.rationale: Feeling trapped with suicide as the only escape is suicidal ideation, though the trapped feeling could also reflect Pessimism.

items.text: I don't care if I live or die at this point.
items.rationale: Indifference to living or dying reflects passive suicidal ideation but could also indicate extreme Sadness or Loss of Pleasure.

items.text: I feel so hopeless about the future that I've thought about whether life is worth continuing.
items.rationale: The hopelessness about the future is rooted in Pessimism, but questioning whether to continue living crosses into suicidal ideation.

items.text: I feel exhausted no matter how much sleep I get.
items.rationale: Persistent exhaustion despite adequate sleep is a hallmark of depressive fatigue.

items.text: I am too tired to do most of the things I need to do.
items.rationale: Fatigue interfering with daily functioning directly maps to this factor.

items.text: Even simple tasks like getting dressed feel physically draining.
items.rationale: Exhaustion from basic activities reflects severe fatigue.

items.text: I feel like I'm moving through mud; everything takes so much more effort than it should.
items.rationale: Psychomotor retardation described as heaviness and increased effort is characteristic of depressive fatigue.

items.text: My body feels heavy and weighed down all the time.
items.rationale: Leaden paralysis or heaviness is a somatic marker of fatigue in depression.

items.text: I get tired much more easily than I used to.
items.rationale: Increased fatigability compared to baseline directly reflects this factor.

items.text: I spend most of the day lying down because I don't have the energy to do anything else.
items.rationale: Behavioral consequence of severe fatigue—spending the day recumbent.

items.text: I feel completely drained of energy from the moment I wake up.
items.rationale: Morning fatigue with no energy upon waking is a classic depressive fatigue symptom.

items.text: I have to force myself to do even the most basic things because I'm so fatigued.
items.rationale: Need for effortful self-motivation due to fatigue clearly maps to this factor.

items.text: My energy levels are so low that I can barely function.
items.rationale: Severely diminished energy with functional impairment.

items.text: I feel physically worn out even though I haven't done anything strenuous.
items.rationale: Fatigue disproportionate to activity level is characteristic of depressive fatigue.

items.text: I need to rest after doing the smallest amount of activity.
items.rationale: Need for frequent rest after minimal exertion reflects severe fatigue.

items.text: I feel so sluggish that it takes me twice as long to complete anything.
items.rationale: Sluggishness and slowed performance map to fatigue but could also reflect psychomotor retardation more broadly.

items.text: I'm so tired that I've lost interest in doing things I normally enjoy.
items.rationale: Fatigue-driven loss of interest could overlap with Loss of Pleasure (anhedonia), though the causal attribution to tiredness anchors it here.

items.text: I'm so exhausted and drained that I can't find pleasure in anything anymore.
items.rationale: The inability to find pleasure overlaps significantly with Loss of Pleasure, though it is attributed to exhaustion.

items.text: I feel like I am a complete failure as a person.
items.rationale: Direct expression of global self-evaluation as a failure, a core feature of the worthlessness construct in the BDI.

items.text: I don't believe I have any value to the people around me.
items.rationale: Perceived lack of interpersonal value is a central component of feelings of worthlessness in depression.

items.text: When I look at my life, I can't find a single thing about myself that matters.
items.rationale: Sweeping self-devaluation and inability to identify personal worth are hallmark cognitive distortions in the worthlessness domain.

items.text: Others would be better off if I had never been born.
items.rationale: Belief that one's existence is a net negative reflects extreme worthlessness, consistent with severe BDI scoring.

items.text: I feel completely useless no matter what I try to do.
items.rationale: Pervasive sense of uselessness across contexts directly taps the worthlessness factor.

items.text: I can't think of anything good about myself.
items.rationale: Inability to generate positive self-attributes is a cognitive marker of worthlessness in Beck's model.

items.text: I see myself as inferior to everyone I meet.
items.rationale: Global social comparison resulting in self-devaluation is a key expression of worthlessness.

items.text: Nothing I do makes any difference, because I'm not worth anything.
items.rationale: Links perceived ineffectiveness directly to self-worth, capturing the core worthlessness cognition.

items.text: I feel like I have let down every person who ever cared about me.
items.rationale: Pervasive sense of having failed others reflects internalized worthlessness and self-blame.

items.text: She describes herself as having no redeeming qualities whatsoever.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of absolute self-devaluation maps directly to the worthlessness construct.

items.text: I am ashamed of who I am at my core.
items.rationale: Deep shame about one's fundamental identity reflects internalized worthlessness rather than situational guilt.

items.text: I contribute nothing meaningful to the world.
items.rationale: Belief in one's lack of meaningful contribution is a direct expression of perceived worthlessness.

items.text: I constantly feel like I'm a burden to my family and friends.
items.rationale: Perceived burdensomeness strongly relates to worthlessness but also overlaps with interpersonal guilt and suicidal ideation constructs.

items.text: I blame myself whenever something goes wrong, even when it's not my fault.
items.rationale: Excessive self-blame is associated with worthlessness but also maps onto the BDI self-criticalness and guilt factors.

items.text: I feel guilty about things I've done and can't stop thinking about my mistakes.
items.rationale: Ruminative guilt can stem from worthlessness but more directly maps to the BDI Guilt factor; the two are highly correlated but conceptually distinct.
